SENT.plain: Changes of the intestinal mucosal barrier are considered to play a role in the pathogenesis of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD)

Our experiments were designed to identify dysregulation of epithelial junctional molecules in the IBD intestinum and to address whether altered expression of these molecules is a primary event in IBD or a phenomenon secondary to the inflammatory process

Noninflamed and inactively and actively inflamed mucosal tissues from patients with ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease as well as tissues from control subjects were analyzed for the expression of junctional molecules by different methods
Marked downregulation of junctional proteins and their respective mRNAs was observed in actively inflamed IBD tissues

In IBD tissues with inactive inflammation, only a few junctional molecules such as E-cadherin and alpha-catenin were affected, whereas expression of desmosomal or tight junction-associated proteins appeared almost unchanged
In noninflamed IBD tissues, junctional protein expression was not different from that seen in normal control subjects
In IBD, downregulation of junctional molecule expression is apparently associated with the inflammatory process and does not likely represent a primary phenomenon
